title: Single Dataset
text:
Exercises

Data:

Using college_recent_grads data from the fivethirtyeight package
Use ?college_recent_grads to review the documentation and glimpse(college_recent_grads) to see the structure of the data


Select, arrange, filter, distinct, count

Which major has the highest percentage of women? (Hint: use arrange(desc()) to easily see the top items)

Output only relevant variables

Get a list of STEM majors that have median earnings < $36,000

(Hint: use the %in% to see if the major_category is in stem_categories)
Output only relevant variables
Use this code to create a list of STEM majors to compare to:



    stem_categories <- c("Biology & Life Science",
                         "Computers & Mathematics",
                         "Engineering",
                         "Physical Sciences")


Output a count of the number of majors in each major_category

mutate, group_by, summarize

Create a new variable called STEM that is a 0/1 indicator if the major is in one of the stem_categories from #2 above.
Which major category has the highest typical (can use mean(), median(), etc.) median income? (Hint: use group_by() and summarize())
Create a scatterplot of median income vs. proportion of women in that major, coloured by whether the major is in a STEM field or not.
As time permits, review the data to create new variables, summarize different aspects, or visualize the data in different ways. Familiarize yourself with ggplot!

title: Data Visualization
text:
Exercises

Load the edibnb.rds data: edibnb<-readRDS("PATHNAME/edibnb.RDS")

Airbnb Listings in Edinburgh with the following data:

id: ID number of the listing
price: Price, in GBP, for one night stay
neighborhood: neighborhood listing is located in
accommodates: Number of people listing accommodates
bathrooms: Number of bathrooms
bedrooms: Number of bedrooms
beds: Number of beds (which can be different than the number of bedrooms)
review_scores_rating: Average rating of property
number_of_reviews: Number of reviews
listing_url: Listing URL

Source: https://www.kaggle.com/datasets/thoroc/edinburgh-inside-airbnb



How many observations (rows) does the dataset have?
Run View(edibnb) in your Console to view the data in the data viewer. What does each row in the dataset represent?
Create a barchart:

Displaying the count of listings in each neighborhood
Add different colors for the number of reviews

Create a visualization that will help you compare the distribution of review scores (review_scores_rating) across neighborhoods.
As time permits, create visualizations to review the price, number of bedrooms, or look at ratings by reviews. Familiarize yourself with ggplot!

2. Install Packages

Load the tidyverse and fivethirtyeight packages into R using library()

title: Getting Started
text:
R vs. RStudio











R is an open-source statistical programming language
R is also an environment for statistical computing and graphics
It’s easily extensible with packages












RStudio is a convenient interface for R called an IDE (integrated development environment), e.g. “I write R code in the RStudio IDE”
RStudio is not a requirement for programming with R, but it’s very commonly used by R programmers and data scientists

title: Getting Started
text:
R packages

Packages are the fundamental units of reproducible R code. They include reusable R functions, the documentation that describes how to use them, and sample data1
As of September 2020, there are over 16,000 R packages available on CRAN (the Comprehensive R Archive Network)2
We’re going to work with a small (but important) subset of these!


1 Wickham and Bryan, R Packages.
2 CRAN contributed packages.

title: Getting Started
section: A short list (for now) of R essentials
text:
A short list (for now) of R essentials

Functions are (most often) verbs, followed by what they will be applied to in parentheses:


do_this(to_this)
do_that(to_this, to_that, with_those)



Packages are installed with the install.packages function and loaded with the library function:


install.packages("package_name")
library(package_name)




File paths should be specified with a forward slash “/”

this is the same for macs, linux systems, and URLs, but is opposite windows
“C:\R_Transition” is the windows path, but in R it needs to be “C:/R_Transition”

title: Getting Started
section: A short list (for now) of R essentials (cont.)
text:
A short list (for now) of R essentials (cont.)

Columns (variables) in data frames are accessed with $:


dataset$variable_name



Assignment/setting values is done with <-


starwars_droids <- starwars %>%
  filter(species == "Droid")




R is case sensitive:

starwars$species is different from StarWars$Species
case_when() is different from CASE_WHEN() and Case_When

title: Getting Started
section: A short list (for now) of R essentials (cont.)
text:
A short list (for now) of R essentials (cont.)

Object documentation can be accessed with ?


?mean



# is how you comment your code


# Here is some code to list Star Wars Droids
starwars %>%                  # starwars dataset
  filter(species == "Droid")  # subset to droids

title: Data and Visualization
text:
Data visualization

“The simple graph has brought more information to the data analyst’s mind than any other device.” — John Tukey


Data visualization is the creation and study of the visual representation of data
Many tools for visualizing data – R is one of them
Many approaches/systems within R for making data visualizations – ggplot2 is one of them, and that’s what we’re going to use

title: Data and Visualization
text:
Mass vs. height

How would you describe the relationship between mass and height of Starwars characters?
What other variables would help us understand data points that don’t follow the overall trend?
Who is the not so tall but really chubby character?

title: Data and Visualization
text: Jabba!

title: Data and Visualization
text:
ggplot2 \(\in\) tidyverse













ggplot2 is tidyverse’s data visualization package
gg in “ggplot2” stands for Grammar of Graphics
Inspired by the book Grammar of Graphics by Leland Wilkinson

title: Data and Visualization
text:
Grammar of Graphics
A grammar of graphics is a tool that enables us to concisely describe the components of a graphic


Source: BloggoType

title: Data and Visualization
text:
Mass vs. height

ggplot(data = starwars, mapping = aes(x = height, y = mass)) +
  geom_point() +
  labs(title = "Mass vs. height of Starwars characters",
       x = "Height (cm)", y = "Weight (kg)")

title: Data and Visualization
text:
Hello ggplot2!

ggplot(data = [dataset],
       mapping = aes(x = [x-variable], y = [y-variable])) +
   geom_xxx() +
   other options

title: Data and Visualization
text:
Aesthetics options
Commonly used characteristics of plotting characters that can be mapped to a specific variable in the data are

colour
shape
size
alpha (transparency)

title: Data and Visualization
text:
Colour

ggplot(penguins,
       aes(x = bill_dep, 
           y = bill_len,
           colour = species)) +
  geom_point()

title: Data and Visualization
text:
Shape
Mapped to a different variable than colour

ggplot(penguins,
       aes(x = bill_dep, 
           y = bill_len,
           colour = species,
           shape = island)) +
  geom_point()

title: Data and Visualization
text:
Shape
Mapped to same variable as colour

       aes(x = bill_dep,

text:
Size

ggplot(penguins,
       aes(x = bill_dep, 
           y = bill_len,
           colour = species,

title: Data and Visualization
text:
Alpha

ggplot(penguins,
       aes(x = bill_dep, 
           y = bill_len,
           colour = species,
           shape = species,
           size = body_mass,
           alpha = flipper_len)) + 
  geom_point() +
  scale_colour_viridis_d()

title: Data and Visualization
text:
Mapping vs. setting

Mapping

ggplot(penguins,
       aes(x = bill_dep,
           y = bill_len,
           size = body_mass,
           alpha = flipper_len)) +
  geom_point()











Setting

ggplot(penguins,
       aes(x = bill_dep,
           y = bill_len)
       ) + 
  geom_point(size = 2, 
             alpha = 0.5)

title: Data and Visualization
text:
Mapping vs. setting

Mapping: Determine the size, alpha, etc. of points based on the values of a variable in the data

goes into aes()

Setting: Determine the size, alpha, etc. of points not based on the values of a variable in the data

goes into geom_*() (this was geom_point() in the previous example)

title: Data Wrangling
text:
Characteristics of tidy data


Each variable forms a column.
Each observation forms a row.
Each type of observational unit forms a table.

title: Data Wrangling
text:
A grammar of data wrangling…
… based on the concepts of functions as verbs that manipulate data frames












select: pick columns by name
arrange: reorder rows
filter: pick rows matching criteria
distinct: filter for unique rows
mutate: add new variables
summarize: agreggation of values
group_by: for grouped operations
… (many more)

title: Data Wrangling
text:
Rules of dplyr functions


First argument is always a data frame
Subsequent arguments say what to do with that data frame
Always return a data frame
Don’t modify in place

title: Data Wrangling
text:
Objects


R is an object oriented programming language
Everything is an object (datasets, arrays, lists, globals, etc.)
Can have multiple datasets, arrays, etc. in your environment

When creating, editing, manipulating data you must first reference the data/object of interest

title: Data Wrangling
text:
Workflow
Say we want to narrow our dataset to only see the name and homeworld variables and sort the data by homeworld



Select

starwars %>%
  select(name, homeworld)

   name               homeworld

Select, then arrange

starwars %>%
  select(name, homeworld) %>%
  arrange(homeworld)

title: Data Wrangling
text:
Pipes
In programming, a pipe is a technique for passing information from one process to another.


Start with the data frame starwars, and pass it to the select() function,



starwars %>%
  select(name, homeworld) %>%
  arrange(homeworld)

title: Data Wrangling
text:
Pipes
In programming, a pipe is a technique for passing information from one process to another.


Start with the data frame starwars, and pass it to the select() function,
then we select the variables name and homeland,



starwars %>%
  select(name, homeworld) %>%
  arrange(homeworld)

title: Data Wrangling
text:
Pipes
In programming, a pipe is a technique for passing information from one process to another.


Start with the data frame starwars, and pass it to the select() function,
then we select the variables name and homeland,
and then we arrange the data frame by homeland



starwars %>%
  select(name, homeworld) %>%
  arrange(homeworld)

# A tibble: 87 × 2
   name                homeworld     
   <chr>               <chr>         
 1 Leia Organa         Alderaan      
 2 Bail Prestor Organa Alderaan      
 3 Raymus Antilles     Alderaan      
 4 Ratts Tyerel        Aleen Minor   
 5 Lobot               Bespin        
 6 Jek Tono Porkins    Bestine IV    
 7 Nute Gunray         Cato Neimoidia
 8 Ki-Adi-Mundi        Cerea         
 9 Mas Amedda          Champala      
10 Mon Mothma          Chandrila     
# ℹ 77 more rows

title: Data Wrangling
text:
How does a pipe work?

You can think about the following sequence of actions - find keys, unlock car, start car, drive to work, park.



Expressed as a set of nested functions in R pseudocode this would look like:


park(drive(start_car(find("keys")), to = "work"))




Writing it out using pipes give it a more natural (and easier to read) structure:


find("keys") %>%
  start_car() %>%
  drive(to = "work") %>%
  park()

title: Data Wrangling
text:
Aside
The pipe operator is implemented in the package magrittr, though we don’t need to load this package explicitly since tidyverse does this for us.













The Treachery of Images
René Magritte

title: Data Wrangling
section: A note on piping and layering
text:
A note on piping and layering


%>% used mainly in dplyr pipelines, we pipe the output of the previous line of code as the first input of the next line of code
+ used in ggplot2 plots is used for “layering”, we create the plot in layers, separated by +

title: Data Wrangling
text:
dplyr
❌

starwars +
  select(name, homeland)

Error: object 'name' not found


✅

starwars %>%
  select(name, homeland)

title: Data Wrangling
text:
ggplot2
❌

ggplot(starwars, aes(x = homeworld, fill = sex)) %>%
  geom_bar()

Error in `geom_bar()`:
! `mapping` must be created by `aes()`.
ℹ Did you use `%>%` or `|>` instead of `+`?


✅

ggplot(starwars, aes(x = homeworld, fill = sex)) +
  geom_bar()

title: Data Wrangling
text:
Code styling
Many of the styling principles are consistent across %>% and +:

always a space before
always a line break after (for pipelines with more than 2 lines)

❌

ggplot(starwars,aes(x=homeworld,fill=sex))+geom_bar()

✅

ggplot(starwars, aes(x = homeworld, fill = sex)) + 
  geom_bar()

title: Working with a single dataset
text:
Select helpers

starts_with(): Starts with a prefix
ends_with(): Ends with a suffix
contains(): Contains a literal string
num_range(): Matches a numerical range like x01, x02, x03
one_of(): Matches variable names in a character vector
everything(): Matches all variables
last_col(): Select last variable, possibly with an offset
matches(): Matches a regular expression (a sequence of symbols/characters expressing a string/pattern to be searched for within text)


See help for any of these functions for more info, e.g. ?everything.

title: Working with a single dataset
text:
Logical operators in R











operator
definition

operator
definition




<
less than

x & y
x AND y


<=
less than or equal to

x | y
x OR y


>
greater than

is.na(x)
test if x is NA


>=
greater than or equal to

!is.na(x)
test if x is not NA


==
exactly equal to

x %in% y
test if x is in y


!=
not equal to

!(x %in% y)
test if x is not in y

title: Working with a single dataset
text:
case_when overview

Multiple if/else statements in a single easy to read format
Assessed in order
If no .default or TRUE statement provided will result in missing data

         ratio_class = case_when(bill_ratio < 2 ~ "small",
                                 bill_ratio > 3 ~ "large")) %>%
  count(species,ratio_class)

title: Working with a single dataset
text:
case_when - final else statement

penguins %>%
  mutate(bill_ratio = bill_len / bill_dep,
         ratio_class = case_when(bill_ratio < 2 ~ "small",
                                 bill_ratio > 3 ~ "large",
                                 TRUE ~ "medium")) %>%
  count(species,ratio_class)



penguins %>%
  mutate(bill_ratio = bill_len / bill_dep,
         ratio_class = case_when(.default = "medium",
                                 bill_ratio < 2 ~ "small",
                                 bill_ratio > 3 ~ "large")) %>%
  count(species,ratio_class)

title: Working with a single dataset
text:
case_when order matters

penguins %>%
  mutate(bill_ratio = bill_len / bill_dep,
         ratio_class = case_when(bill_ratio < 2 ~ "small",
                                 bill_ratio < 3 ~ "medium",
                                 TRUE ~ "large")) %>%
  count(species,ratio_class)



penguins %>%
  mutate(bill_ratio = bill_len / bill_dep,
         ratio_class = case_when(bill_ratio < 3 ~ "medium",
                                 bill_ratio < 2 ~ "small",
                                 TRUE ~ "large")) %>%
  count(species,ratio_class)


left side: - if bill_ratio < 2 then small - else if bill_ratio < 3 then medium - else then large
right side: - if bill_ration < 3 then medium - else if bill_ratio < 2 then small - The small category will never be utilized since the medium will take all < 2 automatically

title: Working with a single dataset
text:
case_when order matters (cont.)

penguins %>%
  mutate(bill_ratio = bill_len / bill_dep,
         ratio_class = case_when(bill_ratio < 2 & sex == "female" ~ "small-female",
                                 bill_ratio < 2 ~ "small-male",
                                 bill_ratio < 3 & sex == "female" ~ "medium-female",
                                 bill_ratio < 3 ~ "medium-male",
                                 sex == "female" ~ "large-female",
                                 TRUE ~ "large-male")) %>%
  count(sex,ratio_class)

                                 bill_ratio < 3 ~ "medium-male",
                                 bill_ratio < 3 & sex == "female" ~ "medium-female",
                                 sex == "female" ~ "large-female",
                                 TRUE ~ "large-male")) %>%
  count(sex,ratio_class)

title: Working with a single dataset
text:
summarize for summary stats


Fun fact: summarize and summarise both work
Hadley Wickham, creator of the tidyverse is from New Zealand
mutate: observation level
summarize: aggregation of data

title: Merging/Joining Multiple Datasets
text:
Joining data frames

something_join(x, y)


left_join(): all rows from x
right_join(): all rows from y
full_join(): all rows from both x and y
semi_join(): all rows from x where there are matching values in y, keeping just columns from x
inner_join(): all rows from x where there are matching values in y, return all combination of multiple matches in the case of multiple matches
anti_join(): return all rows from x where there are not matching values in y, never duplicate rows of x
…

title: Pivoting Data
text:
Why pivot?


Let’s say we want to determine the total cost spent by customer.
We have the items that each customer bought, and the cost per item.
Will be easiest to:

make customer data long, so each row is a purchase
merge on the cost for each item
sum costs by customer

title: Pivoting Data
text:
Customers \(\rightarrow\) purchases


purchases <- customers %>%
  pivot_longer( 
    cols = item_1:item_3,
    names_to = "item_no",
    values_to = "item"
    ) 

purchases %>% 
  left_join(prices, 
            by="item") %>% 
  group_by(customer_id) %>% 
  summarize(total_price = 
              sum(price, 
                  na.rm = TRUE))

# A tibble: 2 × 2
  customer_id total_price
        <dbl>       <dbl>
1           1        1.95
2           2        3.8 




pivot variables item_1 to item_3
column names -> new column called item_no
values in columns -> new column called item
left_join() the prices data to get the cost per item
group_by() and summarize() to get the total price for each customer

haven

SAS:

read_sas() - reads .sas7bdat + .sas7bcat files
read_xpt()- reads SAS transport files
write_xpt() - writes SAS transport files

Stata:

write_dta() - writes .dta files

title: Data Attributes
text:
Data types in R

logical
character
double
integer

title: Data Attributes
text:
Logical & character

logical - boolean values TRUE and FALSE

typeof(TRUE)

[1] "logical"



character - character strings

typeof("hello")

[1] "character"

title: Data Attributes
text:
Double & integer

double - floating point numerical values (default numerical type)

typeof(1.335)

[1] "double"

typeof(7)

[1] "double"



integer - integer numerical values (indicated with an L)

typeof(7L)

[1] "integer"

typeof(1:3)

[1] "integer"

title: Data Attributes
text:
Vectors
Vectors can be constructed using the c() function.

c(1, 2, 3)

[1] 1 2 3

c("Hello", "World!")

[1] "Hello"  "World!"

c(c("hi", "hello"), c("bye", "jello"))

[1] "hi"    "hello" "bye"   "jello"

title: Data Attributes
text:
Converting between types


x <- 1:3
x

[1] 1 2 3

typeof(x)

[1] "integer"





y <- as.character(x)
y

[1] "1" "2" "3"

typeof(y)

[1] "character"

title: Data Attributes
text:
Converting between types


x <- c(TRUE, FALSE)
x

[1]  TRUE FALSE

typeof(x)

[1] "logical"





y <- as.numeric(x)
y

[1] 1 0

typeof(y)

[1] "double"

title: Data Attributes
text:
Converting between types
R will happily convert between various types without complaint when different types of data are concatenated in a vector, and that’s not always a great thing!


c(1, "Hello")

[1] "1"     "Hello"

c(FALSE, 3L)

[1] 0 3




c(1.2, 3L)

[1] 1.2 3.0

c(2L, "two")

[1] "2"   "two"

title: Data Attributes
text:
Explicit vs. implicit coercion
Let’s give formal names to what we’ve seen so far:


Explicit coercion is when you call a function like as.logical(), as.numeric(), as.integer(), as.double(), or as.character()




Implicit coercion happens when you use a vector in a specific context that expects a certain type of vector

title: Data Attributes
text:
Special values

NA: Not available
NaN: Not a number
Inf: Positive infinity
-Inf: Negative infinity




pi / 0

[1] Inf

0 / 0

[1] NaN




1/0 - 1/0

[1] NaN

1/0 + 1/0

[1] Inf

title: Data Attributes
text:
Data classes in R

factor
datetime
data frame
list

title: Data Attributes
text:
Factors
R uses factors to handle categorical variables, variables that have a fixed and known set of possible values

x <- factor(c("BS", "MS", "PhD", "MS"))
x

[1] BS  MS  PhD MS 
Levels: BS MS PhD





typeof(x)

[1] "integer"




class(x)

[1] "factor"




We can think of factors like character (level labels) and an integer (level numbers) glued together

glimpse(x)

 Factor w/ 3 levels "BS","MS","PhD": 1 2 3 2

as.integer(x)

[1] 1 2 3 2

title: Data Attributes
text:
Working with factors
handedness variable in the cat lovers data shows everything imported as categorical

cat_lovers <- read_csv("../data/cat-lovers.csv")
glimpse(cat_lovers)

Rows: 60
Columns: 3
$ name           <chr> "Bernice Warren", "Woodrow Stone", "Willie B…
$ number_of_cats <chr> "0", "0", "1", "3", "3", "2", "1", "1", "0",…
$ handedness     <chr> "left", "left", "left", "left", "left", "lef…

title: Data Attributes
text:
Working with factors - plotting
Keeping handedness as a character outputs in alphabetical order

ggplot(cat_lovers, mapping = aes(x = handedness)) +
  geom_bar()

title: Data Attributes
text:
Use forcats to manipulate factors
Changing handedness to a factor, outputs in level order

cat_lovers %>%
  mutate(handedness = 
           factor(handedness, 
                  level = c("left", "right", "ambidextrous"))) %>%
  ggplot(mapping = aes(x = handedness)) +
  geom_bar()

title: Data Attributes
text:
Come for the functionality …
 stay for the logo



Factors are useful when you have true categorical data and you want to override the ordering of character vectors to improve display




They are also useful in modeling scenarios




The forcats package provides a suite of useful tools that solve common problems with factors

title: Data Attributes
text:
forcats functions



factor(x) turns a vector into a factor vector

default levels are alphabetical
can set level order using levels = argument

levels(f) returns the levels for a factor
fct_count(f) provides a count of the number of cases in each level
fct_unify() standardizes levels across a list of factors





reorder factor levels:

fct_rev(f) reverses the order of the levels
fct_infreq(f) changes the level order based on frequency
and many more

change factor levels:

fct_recode(f, d = "a", e = "b") changes the levels manually
fct_collapse(f, d = c("a", "b")) collapses two or more levels into one
and many more




See https://forcats.tidyverse.org/ for more details

title: Data Attributes
text:
Dates
Two ways to handle dates

as.Date() from base R

y1 <- as.Date("2020-01-01")
y1

[1] "2020-01-01"

typeof(y1)

[1] "double"

class(y1)

[1] "Date"




lubridate from the tidyverse

y2 <- ymd("2020-01-01")
y2

[1] "2020-01-01"

typeof(y2)

[1] "double"

class(y2)

[1] "Date"

title: Data Attributes
text:
lubridate













Create date/time variables from strings or numbers

function name based on the order of the elements in the raw data
ymd() looks for a date in year, month, day format
mdy() looks for a date in month, day, year format
ymd_hms() looks for a datetime in year, month, day, hour, minute, second format

Parse datetime components from a date/time variable

date() will parse just the date component of a datetime variable
year() and hour() will parse just the year and hour components





delimiters are ingored when creating the variables: “2025/07/10” and “20250710” will both create a date variable without having to specify the delimiter

title: Data Attributes
text:
lubridate examples


spss_ex %>% 
  filter(LastConnectionDate != "") %>% 
  mutate(LastDate_Formatted = 
           ymd(LastConnectionDate)) %>%

title: Labelled Data
section: Rename Multiple Variables - All at once
text:
Rename Multiple Variables - All at once
rename_with() allows us to do this across all variables (or a subset of variables)

Important Notes for Quality


Make this change to a new dataset so you can compare and make sure the variable names were assigned correctly
Have a dataset with the old and new variable names as columns so you know the changes are aligned (calling this “metavars”)





df %>% 
  rename_with(~ new_varnames, 
              all_of(old_varnames))

title: Labelled Data
text:
rename_with example


spss_meta_vars %>% 
  select(varname,new_varname)

# A tibble: 57 × 2
   varname            new_varname
   <chr>              <chr>      
 1 CaseId             CaseId     
 2 LastConnectionDate LastConnec…
 3 LastConnectionSta… LastConnec…
 4 ConnectionDuratio… Connection…
 5 ConnectionDuratio… Connection…
 6 LastQuestionFilled LastQuesti…
 7 NumberOfConnectio… NumberOfCo…
 8 resDisposition     resDisposi…
 9 TotalDurationSec   TotalDurat…
10 Device             Device     
# ℹ 47 more rows




spss_meta_vars %>% 
  select(varname,new_varname) %>% 
  filter(str_detect(varname, "^Q7"))

# A tibble: 7 × 2
  varname new_varname
  <chr>   <chr>      
1 Q7C1    Q7_1       
2 Q7C2    Q7_2       
3 Q7C3    Q7_3       
4 Q7C4    Q7_4       
5 Q7C5    Q7_5       
6 Q7C6    Q7_6       
7 Q7_VN   Q7_RF

text:
rename_with example


spss_ex %>% 
  select(starts_with("Q7")) %>%

title: Labelled Data
text:
Relabel Variables
var_label() function from labelled package allows us view labels and set labels


View for a single variable

var_label(spss_ex$Q2)

[1] "Have you ever been in the Military, are you in a college Reserve Officers’ Training Corps (ROTC) program or one of the Service academies, or have you been accepted to and are waiting to begin any of these programs?"





Set for a single varible

var_label(spss_ex$Q2) <- "Q2: Prior military service"
var_label(spss_ex$Q2)

[1] "Q2: Prior military service"

title: Labelled Data
text:
Relabel Multiple variables


var_label(spss_ex$Q2)

[1] "Q2: Prior military service"

var_label(spss_ex$QS)

[1] "What state do you live in?"





spss_ex_newlabel<-spss_ex %>% 
  set_variable_labels(Q2 = "Q2: Ever been in military",
                      QS = "QS: State")




var_label(spss_ex_newlabel$Q2)

[1] "Q2: Ever been in military"

var_label(spss_ex_newlabel$QS)

[1] "QS: State"

title: Labelled Data
section: Relabel Multiple Variables - All at once
text:
Relabel Multiple Variables - All at once
Important Notes for Quality


Make this change to a new dataset so you can compare and make sure the variable labels were assigned correctly
Have a dataset with the varible name and labels as columns so you know the changes are aligned (calling this “metavars”)




spss_meta_vars %>% 
  select(varname, new_label)

# A tibble: 57 × 2
   varname                     new_label                        
   <chr>                       <chr>                            
 1 CaseId                      Case ID                          
 2 LastConnectionDate          Last connection date             
 3 LastConnectionStartTime     Start time of last connection    
 4 ConnectionDurationInSeconds Duration of connection in seconds
 5 ConnectionDurationInMinutes Duration of connection in minutes
 6 LastQuestionFilled          Last question filled             
 7 NumberOfConnections         Number of connections            
 8 resDisposition              Disposition                      
 9 TotalDurationSec            Total Duration (sec.)            
10 Device                      Device                           
# ℹ 47 more rows

title: Labelled Data
text:
Relabel example


spss_meta_vars %>% 
  select(varname,new_label) %>% 
  filter(str_detect(varname,"^Q7"))

# A tibble: 7 × 2
  varname new_label                               
  <chr>   <chr>                                   
1 Q7C1    Q7_1: Race - White                      
2 Q7C2    Q7_2: Race - Black                      
3 Q7C3    Q7_3: Race - American Indian or Alaska …
4 Q7C4    Q7_4: Race - Asian                      
5 Q7C5    Q7_5: Race - Native Hawaiian or other P…
6 Q7C6    Q7_6: Race - Other                      
7 Q7_VN   Q7_RF: Race - Refused                   




spss_ex %>% 
  select(all_of(spss_meta_vars$varname)) %>% 
  set_variable_labels(.labels=spss_meta_vars$new_label) %>% 
  select(starts_with("Q7")) %>% 
  var_label()
